data.title: Fixed GraphicsDevice.Present() to check for current render target.

milestone.title: 3.6 Release
milestone.description: More unit tests, running unit tests on Mac and Linux, SDL2 replacing OpenTK.

data.body: Fixed `GraphicsDevice.Present()` to correctly throw like XNA when RT is set.

data.title: Fix failing XNA tests
data.body:
First off XNA does not support PixelBitmapContent<Byte> as stated in the docs: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/bb198425.aspx#Anchor_1

Then there were some precision errors, so I added some tolerance for comparing the floats.

Lastly MG behaves different from XNA [here](https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/compare/develop...Jjagg:xnaTests?expand=1#diff-d8ef415c6bf96b2f7ba5d6f89b5cb3b0R202). When copying BitmapContent of a float to BitmapContent of Color XNA only sets the red value while MG sets all channels. Should we follow XNA or stick with what we have?

data.title: Sounds Don't Play Consistently on Monogame Android
data.body:
On some Android devices, sound effects don't play consistently. They will either cut out completely for a few seconds at a time, or play fine in one game session, but then not play in another.

I've attached a sample project that shows what happens. On a Kindle Fire HDX, the sounds play consistently, but on a Google Pixel they cut out sporadically. The project should call all the BINGO numbers from B1 to O75 continuously in a loop.

[https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/14806845/MonoGameAndroidAudioTest.zip](https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/14806845/MonoGameAndroidAudioTest.zip)

[Video repro on Google Pixel](https://goo.gl/photos/FQzvk6KAc4oZFVkN6)

data.title: Fix DirectX depthbias
data.body: Fixes #4826

data.title: Fix GL VS attribute caching bug
data.body:
Fixes #4909. The bug is explained in that issue too, but I'll summarize here.

It comes down to that for OpenGL we cache vertex shader attributes based on a hash of the vertex shader, but when an attribute is not used in the current shader program the compiler will optimize it out and asking the location of that attribute will return -1. That value will be cached however and when another technique with the same vertex shader is later applied, the cached value of the location of that attribute will be fetched even though it might be used and does not actually have location -1. The fix I applied, as suggested by @ed022, is to hash based on the current program, i.e. a hash based on the hash of the vertex and pixel shader. I used the same hash that's used for caching shader programs.

data.title: Idea on how to determine if the requested feature should be added to MonoGame
data.body:
I've been playing around with audio visualization and I started questioning why XNA even had it in the first place, which made me come to an idea on the questions we need to ask in case someone requests a new feature:

1) How many different ways are there to implement it?
2) Does it require a per platform implementation?
3) Is the feature useful enough for inclusion?

If the answer to 1. is only one way, or the answer to 2. is yes than we should probably implement it.

Few things I tried with questions above:

**Audio visualization:**
1) Only 1 way, you always get the same numbers
2) No

Conclusion: **Yes**

**Mouse input:**
1) Only 1 way, you always read the same input stuff
2) Yes

Conclusion: **Yes**

**Font processor/importer**
1) Only 1 way to read/process/display the data
2) Yes

Conclusion: **Yes**

**Random function:**
1) There are multiple random algorithms
2) No

Conclusion: **No**

**Custom GUI controls:**
1) There are multiple ways of implementation
2) No

Conclusion: **No**

**Tiled Map content pipeline**
1) There is only 1 way to read the tiled map data, but multiple ways to process/display it
2) No

Conclusion: **No** 

@tomspilman @KonajuGames @dellis1972 Thoughts?

EDIT1: Added the 3rd question

data.title: SDL 2.0.5 not in dev build installer even though dependent code changes are
data.body:
@cra0zy This is specifically related to some changes you made.

I just updated my Monogame install to the latest dev build (specifically 3.6.0.1246) after a couple months (was running an old dev build).

When I tried running my game, I was getting an exception when trying to enable window resizing viz.             Window.AllowUserResizing = true;

The exception was: "SDL 2.0.4 does not support changing resizable parameter of the window after it's already been created".

It looks like this change was made by you ~2 months ago:

https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/commit/e9368c49e7a2ec6aa3e29cb9f33247ecedfc8555

It seems that even though the code changes for this are in the latest dev installer, the actual SDL2.dll that is bundled is version 2.0.4 and not version 2.0.5.

I manually updated my DLL to 2.0.5 and that seems to have fixed the problem.

It would be great to get the updated DLL into the installer as well.

Thanks.

data.title: fixed touch handling bug
data.body: This is a small obvious fix for a little bug: when using .RemoveAt() with List<>, it should be iterated backward.

data.title: OpenAL initialization failing quite often
data.body:
Hello,

This is a problem that I never encountered locally, but our crash database is filled with these kind of crashes and we have several players complaining about it.

```OggStream``` ctor crashes at times, with ```External component has thrown an exception```, which makes it quite hard to understand remotely and would indicates that the native side of OpenAL-Soft is failing.

It happens on a simple ```Content.Load<Song>()```. No threading involved. Here's the full stack trace:

```
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.OpenALSoundController.ReserveSource()
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Audio.OggStream..ctor(String filename, Action finishedAction, Int32 bufferCount)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.Song.PlatformInitialize(String fileName)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.Song..ctor(String fileName, Int32 durationMS)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.SongReader.Read(ContentReader input, Song existingInstance)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentTypeReader`1.Read(ContentReader input, Object existingInstance)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.InnerReadObject[T](T existingInstance)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadObject[T]()
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentReader.ReadAsset[T]()
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadAsset[T](String assetName, Action`1 recordDisposableObject)
   at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load[T](String assetName)
```

The thing is that ```OpenALSoundController.ReserveSource()``` doesn't make any call to OpenAL, so the problem may be elsewhere.

Note that by the time this code is reached, we already successfully initialized the device and loaded a few ```SoundEffect``` before loading the ```Song```, which indicates that the AL device and buffers initializations are doing fine until song loading.

If anyone has inputs regarding this issue, that would be very welcome. I haven't been able to reproduce it.

data.title: GetData<T> Array issue
data.body:
Hello,
I assume that I could reproduce a bug in which the specified GetData method ( with startIndex and count) wants an array of size [startIndex + count] instead of [count].
The main problem is now that the array of the size [startIndex + count] is filled to index [startIndex] with standard values .
Not until index[startIndex] the whole array is filled with dumb.
Only from index [startIndex] to the end of the array are the requested vertices.

Is there no possibility to acquire only those vertices between startIndex and count ? Otherwise too much redundancy is present.


Best regards,
net developer

data.title: Net namespace rewrite
Extract wave blockalign for adpcm format from RIFF header
data.body:
This is a fix for the problem discussed here: https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/4446

The block alignment of ADPCM wave files is extracted from the RIFF header and overrides what is calculated in DefaultAudioProfile.ProbeFormat.

data.title: WinDX: Fixed potential crash when setting MediaPlayer.Volume
data.body:
I'm fairly confident this fixes #4298

In certain circumstances, setting `MediaPlayer.Volume` could cause a crash. I actually managed to reliably reproduce this by continually setting the volume and playing a new song every few seconds.

The cause of the crash was due to the code not properly considering that different threads could be messing with the volume controller. So if `MediaPlayer.Volume` was being set at the same time that a new song started playing, an exception could occur.

The fix was to simply use a lock when dealing with the volume controller. After adding the lock, I could no longer reproduce this crash.

data.title: Android project file missing : MonoGame.Framework.Android.csproj and Lidgren.Netwrok.Android.csproj
WinDX: Fix to find closest available mode for CurrentDisplayMode
data.body:
**UPDATE 29-Dec: As per discussion, changed this to force the current display mode to the desktop resolution even if it's not an available mode.**

I've found that `GraphicsAdapter.CurrentDisplayMode` can sometimes be null in certain circumstances because the reported desktop resolution isn't one of the available modes. This PR attempts to find the next closest mode if a mode matching the desktop resolution isn't found.

An example of this happening that I saw was crash reports showing 2715x1527 as the desktop resolution, but modes only going up to 1920x1080. After some digging I found that 2715x1527 is a resolution associated with an NVIDIA feature called Dynamic Super Resolution (DSR). I tried enabling this feature on my machine, but when I did it actually showed 2715x1527 as an available mode. So I can only assume that the machines with this problem somehow had their DSR settings messed up. So at least with this PR, `CurrentDisplayMode` falls back to the next closest resolution on these machines.

data.title: WinDX: Fix to ensure window is maximised when starting in fullscreen
data.body:
I came across a rare problem which seemed to only show up on older/slower computers. Sometimes when starting in borderless fullscreen (i.e. `HardwareModeSwitch = false`), the window would not get maximised.

After some investigation, I could see that it was maximised at first but was then immediately restored to it's original size after that. It turns out the problem was that `Form.Show` was being called twice - once in `WinFormsGameWindow.Initialize` (via `WinFormsGamePlatform.BeforeInitialize`), and again in `WinFormsGameWindow.RunLoop`. So to fix this, I simply changed `WinFormsGamePlatform.BeforeInitialize` to only set the form's `ClientSize`, and let `RunLoop` call `Show` afterwards.

data.title: WinDX: Frame latency fix
data.body:
I recently found an issue in MonoGame while investigating some frame latency issues in my game. The maximum frame latency was being set to 3 frames when v-sync was disabled.

The problem was that it seems to have been confused with the sync interval setting ([documentation on sync interval](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/bb174576(v=vs.85).aspx)). So when v-sync was disabled, the frame latency was set to 0 (which means to use the default value of 3) ([documentation on maximum frame latency](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ff471334(v=vs.85).aspx)).

The PR fixes it so that the maximum frame latency is always 1. I've also tidied up some things to make the code clearer.

data.body:
Add support for reading 24-bit DDS images, setting the alpha channel to opaque.

Fixes #5345

data.title: Fixed some compiler warnings
data.body: Some low-hanging fruit amongst the compiler warnings.

data.title: [Linux Installer] Check for monodevelop-stable
data.body:
Currently there is no way for Linux users to get MonoDevelop 6 and MonoGame easily (unless they are running Arch Linux), so I decided to make a MD 6 general purpose Linux installer (https://github.com/cra0zy/monodevelop-run-installer) and to make sure that I don't conflict with the existing version I named commands with `-stable` suffix.

This PR simply adds `monodevelop-stable` as a possible MonoDevelop command to the installer.

data.title: Really struggling to compile Monodevelop from source
data.body:
Hey there.

Since Monodevelop 6 Flatpak doesn't work with Monogame, I was told to try and compile from source. After following this guide:

https://kvssoft.wordpress.com/2016/12/13/building-monodevelop-on-ubuntu/

I have received these errors: 

`Errors:

/home/ashley/Applications/MonoDevelop/6.1.2.44/main/Main.sln (default targets) ->
(Build target) ->
/home/ashley/Applications/MonoDevelop/6.1.2.44/main/external/fsharpbinding/MonoDevelop.FSharpBinding/MonoDevelop.FSharp.fsproj (default targets) ->
/usr/lib/mono/4.5/Microsoft.FSharp.Targets (CoreCompile target) ->

	FSC: error FS0193: The module/namespace 'Gdk' from compilation unit 'gdk-sharp' did not contain the namespace, module or type 'EventClient'
	/home/ashley/Applications/MonoDevelop/6.1.2.44/main/external/fsharpbinding/MonoDevelop.FSharpBinding/Services/FSharpConsoleView.fs(41,6): error FS1109: A reference to the type 'Gdk.EventClient' in assembly 'gdk-sharp' was found, but the type could not be found in that assembly
`

Now it actually was working, I had it compiled and built on my desktop. I decided though that now it was working, I thought it'd be a better idea to move it to a more, out the way folder. It stopped working, nor did it work when I started from scratch and recompile it, nor did it work if I tried going back to the desktop. This is so frustrating :/ Any tips?

data.title: Avoid IndexOutOfRangeException when fc-match returns no matches
data.body:
This change avoids the `IndexOutOfRangeException` that's currently being thrown if `fc-match` doesn't return any matches at all, e.g. if `fc-match` (`fontconfig`) isn't installed.

The exception prevents building spritefonts even when `fc-match` isn't actually needed, such as when the font file is located in the same directory as the `.spritefont` file.

The program already handles the case when `fc-match` fails to find the correct font. I simply handle this "not installed" case the same as the "no match" case.

data.title: Projects importing monogame pipeline targets are never skipped.
data.body:
Any project which includes this line 
`<Import Project="..\MonoGame\MonoGame.Framework.Content.Pipeline\MonoGame.Content.Builder.targets" />`
ends up ALWAYS having its "Build" target execute, every time you build, and every time you start debugging, even when nothing has changed. It will never ever ever appear as "skipped" in the build output.

data.title: PipelineTool incorrectly showing items in root instead of beneath folder
data.body:
Note that I am running on windows.

The following line will show the item "dice_award" beneath the "Audio" folder.
`/build:Audio/dice_award.wav`

The following line will incorrectly show the item "dice_award" directly in the tree root (it still builds correctly).
`/build:Audio\dice_award.wav`
